The species is known from five Greek islands in the eastern Aegean (Lesvos, Samos, Chios, Ikaria, Fournoi (Huber 2020).

All Roever's citations of Pholcus opilionoides (Schrank, 1781) in Crete (1928 & 1959) are considered here as Hoplopholcus labyrinthi (Kulczyński, 1903). According to Brignioli (1979) and Bosmans et al. (2013), these citations were erroneous. Bosmans et al. (2013), after the re-examination of Roewer’s material from Sarchos cave, they assigned all these citations to Hoplopholcus labyrinthi (Kulczyński, 1903) and excluded P. olilionoides from the spider's list of Crete as they didn’t collect it during extensive sampling. Furthermore, H. labyrinthi was misidentified in previous publications as H. minotaurinus in the caves of Megalo Katofygi, Koufota, Karoubes and Milatos (Huber 2020). The species is widely distributed in Crete, known mostly from caves.

H. minotaurinus was misidentified in previous publications as H. labyrinthi in the caves of Doxa, and Neraidospilios (Irakleio) and the cave of Trapeza (Lasithi) (Huber 2020). The species is restricted to eastern Crete (Lasithi).
Known from Crete, southern Greece, the Aegean Islands, and western and southern Turkey (Huber 2020).

Sturany (1904) reports  Hypnophila zacynthia from an undefined cave of the Mt. Pantokratoras in Kerkyra, which was then tentatively identified as the Katsouri Cave near Mparmpati where S. collasi was re-discovered (Gittenberger 2000).
Only known from the type locality.
Known from few localities on Taygetos Mt. Erroneously reported as L. peloponnensiacus by Casale (1988)
Reported from few locations on Chelmos, Menalon and Kyllini Mts (North Peloponnisos).

Comments: S. collasi was described by Sturany (1904) from an undefined cave of the Mt. Pantokratoras in Kerkyra, which was then tentatively identified as the Katsouri Cave near Mparmpati where the species was re-discovered (Gittenberger 2000).

Distribution: Europe,      North Africa,      Turkey,      temperate Asia to China,      Korea,      Japan

Comments: Only known from the type locality.

Europe,     Turkey,     Caucasus,     Central Asia,     China
N coasts of Mediterranean to the Aegean sea

Comments: Sulcia cretica is endemic to Greece. There sub-species have been described: S. cretica cretica Fage, 1945 (Crete Island), S. cretica lindbergi Dresco, 1962 (known only from the cave of Perama, Ipeiros) and S. cretica violacea Brignoli, 1974 (Ionian islands, continental Greece)

Comments: Only known from the type locality

Known from 10 caves and a few non-cave  sites in Crete. Synonymy: Tegenaria labyrinthi Brignoli (1984) [Bolzer 2010, Bolzer et al. 2013]; Tegenaria bayeri Kratochvil, 1934 [Roewer 1959, misidentification]. Endemic to Kriti (in caves).
Brignoli (1979a) notes that the citations by Roewer (1959) should be considered doubtful.
Only known from the type locality.

Distribution: Europe,      North Africa to Israel and Central Asia
Comments: All citations of Tegenaria ferruginea (Panzer, 1804) were erroneus and assighned to Tegenaria parietina (Fourcroy, 1785) [Brignoli 1979b, Bosmans & Chatzaki 2005, Bosmans et al. 2013, Bolzern 2010, Bolzern et al. 2013]
Only known from 3 caves in eastern Crete
The citation by Roewer (1959) considered doubtful by Brignoli (1979b)

Distribution: Europe,     Macaronesia,     Northern Africa,     Turkey,     Caucasus,     Central Asia

Comments: Synonymy: Monodella argentarii Stella, 1951. Wagner (1994) notes that most probably the specimens collected from Alepotrypa (Rouch 1974) and Glyfada cave (Rouch 1964, Bou 1975) belong to the species Tethysbaena aiakos Wagner, 1994.

Distribution: Europe,    Turkey,    Caucasus,    Russia to Kazakhstan

Comments: Western and southern Greece from Epirus to Crete. Synonymy: Trachelipus palustris (Strouhal, 1937), Tracheoniscus trachealis (Budde-Lund, 1885) [Schmalfuss 2003 & Schmalfuss et al. 2004]
Only known from the type locality and a nearby cave.

Known from the Aegean islands Naxos, Iraklia, Tílos and Crete. Possible synonymies between T. lindbergi, T. cavernicola, and T. intermedius. The taxonomy of the group species needs further investigation (Schmalfuss et al. 2004).
Schmalfus (2003) remarks that the records of this species from Greece seem to pertain to T. rhodiensis
Possible synonymies between T. lindbergi, T. cavernicola, and T. intermedius. The taxonomy of this species group (including T. euboensis) needs further investigation (Schmalfuss et al. 2004).

Known from the central mainland of Greece and the Aegean islands Evvoia, Tinos and Crete. Possible synonymies between T. lindbergi, T. cavernicola, and T. intermedius. The taxonomy of this species group (including T. euboensis) needs further investigation (Schmalfuss et al. 2004).

Only known from the type locality. The record of T. spinulosus (Bacceti 1992) from Santorini island (cave Agios Nikolaos, leg. Cobolli 10.9.1988) should be attributed to Troglophilus marinae from Spilaio Zoodochou Pigis as Rampini et Di Russo (2003) studied the very specimens collected by Cobolli.
Karaman et al. (2001) note that the cited species  could belong to T. zorae

Bacceti (1992) records T. spinulosus from Santorini island (cave Agios Nikolaos, leg. Cobolli 10.9.1988). Presumably, this record should be attributed to Troglophilus marinae from Spilaio Zoodochou Pigis as Rampini et Di Russo (2003) studied Cobolli's collected specimens.

Species_Full_Name: Troglophilus zoiai Di Russo, Rampini & Cobolli, 2014
Comments: Known from caves in Fokida sub-Region. According to Di Russo et al. (2014) the historical record of Troglophilus (=Rhaphidophora) cavicola by Brunner Von Wattenwyl (1861) should be assigned to Troglophilus zoia.

Comments: Found in the debris of a jar and the gills of the Austropotamobius torrentium specimen collected in the river at 7,100 m from the cave entrance in 2002 (Subchev et al. 2007).

Triturus cristatus was mistakenly included in the list of the cave Alistrati fauna (Paragamian 1992). A living individual of Salamandra salamandra was observed and photographed at the floor of the enterance pit (March 9, 1989).
Recorded as Mastus pupa cretensis (Pfeiffer, 1848), (Frank 1988). Both records are from cave entrances.
Recorded as Albinaria inflata infiata (Olivier, 1801) at the entrances of the caves Neraidospilios and Agia Paraskevi (Frank 1988).
Recorded at the entrance of the cave
Synonymy: Helix (Pseudocampylaea) pellita  (Férussac, 1832). Recorded from the entrance of the cave (Martens 1889).

Locus_Typicus_Cave: Small anonymous cave at Lasithi plateau

Species_Full_Name: Duvalius marijkeae Casale, Giachino, Vailiati & Felix, 2017

Comments: Synonymy: Pterostichus seticeps G.Müller, 1934

The Euscorpius carpathicus species group from Sifnos, Paros, Naxos, and Antiparos was synonymised with Euscorpius tauricus by Tropea et al (2017, Ecologia Montenegrina 7:614-638). Euscorpius from Irakleia, an island very close to Naxos, is considered here as E. tauricus.
Käufel (1930) cites P. compressa from “Höhle am Pantokrator, 200 m. 3.4.1929”. This could be the cave Katsouri.

Synonymy: Troglophilus neglectus serbicus Mařan, 1958

Cited be Beron et al (2011) as Troglophilus serbicus Mařan, 1958

Distribution: Slovakia,   Italy,   Corsica,   Czech Republic,   Austria,   Greece

Comments: The subspecies Montenegrina dofleini prespaensis Nordsieck, 1988, endemic to Lake Prespa area, with sporadical occurrences along the western and southern shores.
The subspecies Montenegrina hiltrudae sattmanni Nordsieck, 1988 distributed at the area of the Prespa Lakes.

Protection_Status: Presidential Decree 67/1981 on the protection of native flora and fauna species (OGG 23/A/1981)|Bern Convection: Appendix II in Council of Europe 1979 - Convention on the conservation of European wildlife and natural habitats / Law 1335/1983, OGG 32/Α/14-03-1983 (Integration of the Bern Convention)|Habitats Directive (92/43/EEC): Appendix IV / Joined Ministerial Decision 33318/3028/1998, OGG 1289/Β/1998 (Integration of the Habitats Directive 92/43/EEC)
Presidential Decree 67/1981 on the protection of native flora and fauna species (OGG 23/A/1981)
Comments: Di Russo et al. (2018) report that “except for the type locality, cave cricket populations obviously belonging to the same species were observed in six other caves or old mines of the island, all by Giorgos Anousakis and Vasilis Tsigonias: a) cave of Agios Georgios (37°01.287’N, 025°12.776’E), on the same hill and on the same day as the type material. This is a much smaller cave situated at an altitude of 358 m, a few meters away from the Monastery of Agios Georgios; b) cave of Krevatarias (37°02.802’N, 025°10.889’E), visited on 28.XII.2014, situated on Mt Agioi Pantes, at the altitude of 656 m; c) unnamed pitfall (37°01.410’N, 025°11.169’E), at the area of Langada, south of Paros town, at an altitude of 610 m, visited on 18.IV.2015; d) two abandoned mines, a few meters away from each other, (37°03.267’N, 025°09.876’E), at the area of Aliparta, west of the town of Paros, at an altitude of 455 m, visited on 11.XII.2016; e) cave To Moutsno (37°03.216’N, 025°11.039’E), Mt Agioi Pantes, at an altitude of 557 m, visited on 02.IV.2017; and f ) Pitfall Sti Xoni (37°02.224’N, 025°11.189’E), Mt Agioi Pantes, at an altitude of 584 m, visited on 27.IV.2017.”

Protection_Status: Presidential Decree 67/1981 on the protection of native flora and fauna species (OGG 23/A/1981)

Comments: Endemic to Kriti island, found in several locations (Malicky 2005).

Species_Full_Name: Tsoukatosia christinae A. Reischütz & P.L. Reischütz, 2003
Comments: The species was described from empty shells. It was later found at a few more sites on the western side of the Taigetos Mts. (Reischütz et al. 2016).
Known from the cave Inamila (Evvoia) and from MMS habitat in Voiotia (Panassós Mt), Fokida (Vardoússia Mt), Argolida (Parnon Mt), Arkadia (Saita Mt, Pleiovouni Mt),

Hypogean species inhabiting subterranean and soil habitats, found in six caves, one mine and two soil and MSS habitats in the Austrian, Italian, Slovenian and Swiss Alps (Sendra 2020). The specimens found in Ermis cave have a significant resemblance to P. caprae and were recorded as Plusiocampa (Plusiocampa) cf. caprai Condé, 1950  (Sendra 2020).
Known only from the type locality and two more sites in central Crete.
Known from several localities of western Crete (Chatzaki & Komnenov 2019).

Distribution: Canary Islands, North Africa, Anatolia, Caucasus, C-S Europe
Introduced to USA, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Europe, Macaronesia, North Africa to Kyrgyzstan.
